docs.lead_paragraph: SMART MONEY'S September issue is a prime example of why this personal finance magazine has succeeded in a very crowded field. For starters, the editor in chief, Steven Swartz, writes in an Editor's Page column that his magazine doesn't have a clue if this summer's stock market correction is over. He also acknowledges that Smart Money's record on forecasting the '96 correction was a mixed bag. And he confesses that the funds selected in last month's cover article -- ''The Seven Best New Funds'' -- ''marched right into the hurricane'' and ''went down along with the rest of the market.'' They were not, he concedes, as flexible as hoped. Luckily for investors, that article hit the newsstands after the market's biggest drops.

headline.main: When a Magazine Isn't Afraid to Look in the Mirror

docs.abstract: Comment on crowded field of magazines devoted to personal finance; Smart Money is cited as magazine that is willing to admit mistakes, and analyze its own track record; other magazines mentioned are Money, Worth and Kiplinger's Personal Finance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. MICHAEL KRAMER is an internist and cardiologist who practices on the Upper East Side on Manhattan. But lately he has been spending as much time managing his Manhattan Primary Care medical group and physicians' network as he does with patients. In the managed-care environment of the 1990's, solo practices are rapidly diminishing. Doctors who have treasured their ground-floor offices on Park and Fifth Avenues are moving out and joining with others in larger spaces to reduce their overhead.

headline.main: For Doctors, Togetherness Is the New Way of Life

docs.abstract: Doctors in New York are forsaking their private ground-flood offices for group practices and networks to reduce their overhead in the era of managed care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Crows Over a WheatField By Paula Sharp. 404 pp. New York: Hyperion. $22.95. CHILD abuse and custody battles are the closest most modern Americans come to real tragedy - the unstoppable playing out of a conflict that reveals only the worst in the participants and in the end challenges the very concept of hope. These issues, whether told in fiction or nonfiction, can't help being dramatic and involving, but they almost always have a hectic edge to them, the effect of too many events piling into too little time. By the first moment the abuse is discovered or the custody battle joined, the most important good - the child's mental health - already seems lost, and every subsequent event seems certain to compound the loss with additional damage. Paula Sharp, the author of three earlier novels and a translator of Latin American fiction, bravely wrestles with this intransigent material in her new novel and manages to illuminate some aspects of it with fresh insights. But in ''Crows Over a Wheatfield'' she is finally defeated, because the tone and the events of the novel, which spans 35 years, are somewhat at odds. Ms. Sharp would like to be poking gentle fun at the life and habits of folks in northern Wisconsin (admittedly an idiosyncratic region), but she would also like to be evoking terror and making some sharp observations about the American judiciary system. Ultimately, the mix doesn't quite convince me. The elements are promising, though. The narrator, Melanie Ratleer, and her half brother, Matthew, are the children of Joel Ratleer, a singularly cruel and abusive man. A criminal defense lawyer, he is already famous and admired throughout the Midwest by the mid-1950's. The turning point in the relationship between the father and his children comes in 1965 through a locally notorious case in which a housekeeper coldly murders three small children in her care. While everyone, including the murderer, acknowledges her guilt, Joel Ratleer manages to get her off by impugning the character of the children's father. The moral corruption of the case is so vicious that even the defendant protests. Fifteen-year-old Matthew, forced by his father to help him on the case, responds by taking a considerable quantity of LSD. He becomes psychotic and is institutionalized. This section only serves, however, as a prologue. Melanie, who goes off to become an insurance lawyer and then a judge in New York, is later drawn through Matt and her stepmother into two Wisconsin custody battles involving Mildred Steck, a woman Melanie finds charismatic and admirable. After disappearing in the 1970's to protect her son from his abusive father, Mildred surfaces in the 90's as the founder of the Railroad, a network of small anarchic cells that provide escape and safe haven for parents and children caught in the Family Court system. According to Ms. Sharp, a practicing criminal lawyer in New York, this system has no redeeming, or even neutral, qualities. Through it, children and their parents (sometimes men, but most often women) are routinely destroyed by the moral corruption of individual judges and the legal tricks of top-dollar lawyers, who twist the intent of often ill-thought-out and oddly assorted state laws to punish victims of domestic violence and insure their continued victimization, sometimes unto death. The mere quest for survival forces the victims of these courts underground, where they take on new names and identities, move far away and attempt to disappear, at least until their children are 18 and no longer subject to custody. Ms. Sharp develops her indictment of the legal system as a novelist should - with vivid stories that get the reader riled up. Clearly, she brings knowledge of the law to bear on the subject - the courtrooms and lawyers she describes are convincing and detailed. But the very color of the stories finally causes this reader to draw back: if it is this bad, why isn't Ms. Sharp writing nonfiction - with many more examples, an objective tone and wide-ranging statistics? I am riled up, yes, but I believe I am being used a bit, the way novelists almost always use you, not for a larger purpose but for suspense only. This, I believe, is called exploitation. What I think Ms. Sharp is trying to do, through Melanie Ratleer, is to link the personal and the professional, the child and the adult. Melanie is open about how her own abuse and the insanity of her brother have molded her - she's become a law-obsessed machine who hardly speaks, is unmarried and isolated, and works almost 24 hours a day. She enormously admires Mildred, the founder of the Railroad, who is filled with energy, self-reliant, creative, beautiful and brave. Though Mildred's spiritual ancestor is supposedly John Brown, Ms. Sharp doesn't dare make her as problematic a character as Brown was - she is nonviolent and rational. But Ms. Sharp's attempt to have it all - both Melanie's salvation and her condemnation of the judicial system, both comedy and tragedy - doesn't quite work. For the sake of the comedy, all of Melanie's friends are lovely and benign, wise and good. For the sake of the tragedy, all of the minions of the corrupt courts are ugly, foolish, evil and mysterious. The most enjoyable parts of the novel, for me, are the peripheral bits, and these show that Ms. Sharp is clearly a writer of significant talents. She brings precision and lyricism to her descriptions of northern Wisconsin, evoking quite neatly both the darkness of the winter and the brightness of the summer. There are nice touches, too, in the peculiarities of such local sights as a giant neon yellow muskie (a type of pike) and a store sign advertising ''Liquor - beer - cheese - bakery - live bait,'' all the pleasures of Wisconsin outside of Madison. She brings the House on the Rock into the literary arena, and Spring Green and Frank Lloyd Wright's home, Taliesin. This beautiful sense of place, though, is crying out to be in another novel, one in which it is more than scenery. Even so, ''Crows Over a Wheatfield'' does ask serious questions about issues that many Americans deal with only reluctantly. That the novelist cannot resolve them is a testament to their importance and their mind-numbing difficulty.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS many as one out of three Connecticut residents may get cancer. Few, however, know that details of their cancer, its treatment and outcome are recorded in the oldest population-based cancer registry in the United States. The Connecticut Tumor Registry, officially established in 1941, includes all reported cancer diagnosed in state residents from 1935 onward. All hospitals and pathology laboratories are required by state law to report incidences of cancer, along with information on follow-up.

headline.main: Keeping Track of Cancer in the State

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert's ''Mugged in the Hospital'' (column, Aug. 9) only gets part of the story regarding the apparently truncated hospitalization of the woman on Long Island operated on by Patrick Vetere, M.D. Mr. Herbert is too quick to condemn the utilization management policies of Prudential HealthCare. This was a routine general surgical procedure. Patients who undergo routine general surgical procedures are almost always discharged on the day they eat their first normal meal successfully and are no longer dependent upon skilled nursing care or intravenous support.

headline.main: Don't Rush to Demonize Managed Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Charles A Derrow letter disputes Bob Herbert's Aug 9 Op-Ed article on managed care (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Bob Herbert's ''Mugged in the Hospital'' (column, Aug. 9) only gets part of the story regarding the apparently truncated hospitalization of the woman on Long Island operated on by Patrick Vetere, M.D. Mr. Herbert is too quick to...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert's ''Mugged in the Hospital'' (column, Aug. 9) is significant because of what it doesn't say. Mr. Herbert ignores the fact that all the parties involved in the case he writes about, involving a woman admitted to a Long Island hospital for a hysterectomy -- the doctor, the patient and the hospital -- were told one month before the surgery that a three-day, two-night hospital stay had been approved. As in all such cases, we want to make sure everyone involved understands what to expect. Furthermore, if there had been complications or abnormalities after the surgery indicating a longer hospital stay was warranted, we would have routinely approved it. There were no complications or abnormalities, and the patient had a full and speedy recovery.

headline.kicker: Don't Rush to Demonize Managed Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert's ''Mugged in the Hospital'' (column, Aug. 9) is right on. Unless the public and the news media persist in noting these outrages perpetrated by the insurance companies, they will surely worsen. I participated in a similar exercise involving the Harvard Community Health Plan. The utilization review nurse couldn't understand why I had not discharged a 7-year-old boy within 36 hours of his surgery for appendicitis. She neither saw the patient nor read the chart, nor could she understand my astonishment at her stupidity. Her employer said that there was simply a ''professional disagreement.''

headline.kicker: Don't Rush to Demonize Managed Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Joseph R Barrie letter lauds Bob Herbert's Aug 9 Op-Ed article on managed care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: There is no reason for Bob Herbert to be offended by the conduct of the health-care insurers he describes (''Mugged in the Hospital,'' column, Aug. 9). Through interpretations of Federal legislation, health maintenance organizations and insurance companies have been allowed deliberately to delay approval of lifesaving medical procedures until after severe deterioration had taken place in the patient's life. Two cases that quickly come to mind are Kuhl v. Lincoln National Health Plan of Kansas City in the Eighth Circuit (delay in approval of coronary bypass), and Cannon v. Group Health Service of Oklahoma in the 10th Circuit (delay in approval of high-dose chemotherapy for breast cancer).

headline.kicker: Don't Rush to Demonize Managed Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Hollywood has never been too sure how to treat politicians and journalists, portraying them as either heroic or contemptible, either utterly decent and selfless or recklessly ambitious and back stabbing. But now two movie projects -- a big-budget adaptation of the best-selling novel ''Primary Colors'' and a drama about Janet Cooke, the disgraced Washington Post reporter -- are seeking to redefine the worlds of politicians and journalists as more ambiguous and morally complex. Mike Nichols, who is directing ''Primary Colors,'' said it was precisely the ambiguities of the central character, a flawed Presidential candidate with apparent similarities to Bill Clinton, that led to his decision to turn the book into a film. (Universal gave Mr. Nichols one of the most lucrative deals ever for a director, earning him millions of dollars.)

headline.main: Of Politics And News: Two Films From Life

docs.abstract: Director Mike Nichols comments on making film adaptation of novel Primary Colors, phone interview; Mike Sager and Janet Cooke comment on their deal with Tri-Star Pictures for film based on Sager's article about Cooke, who won and lost Pulitzer Prize for 1981 article for Washington Post that proved to be hoax, phone interviews; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State's ambitious proposal to move almost all of its 3.5 million Medicaid recipients into managed care plans took a major step forward yesterday as the Federal Government announced the terms under which it would approve the plan. State officials immediately called the conditions generally acceptable, predicting that the plan would be in place by the end of the year. The plan would require that all Medicaid recipients who are not in nursing homes get their health care through health maintenance organizations, in the hope of providing improved health care for the poor as well as curtailing costs in a program whose price has recently ballooned to $24 billion annually. About half that is borne by the state.

headline.main: U.S. Sets Terms for State to Shift Medicaid to Managed Care
